conclusion: Determine the instantaneous value of the induced current and the average value of the induced EMF as the wire frame rotates through 60 degrees.
The induced EMF in a rotating loop can be found using Faraday's law: \( \mathcal{E} = B \cdot A \cdot \omega \cdot \sin(\theta) \).
The induced current \( I \) in the loop can be found using Ohm's law: \( I = \frac{\mathcal{E}}{R} \).
Substitute \( \mathcal{E} \) to find \( I = \frac{\sqrt{3} B S \omega}{2 R} \).
The instantaneous value of the induced current is \( \boxed{\frac{\sqrt{3} B S \omega}{2 R}} \).
The average value of the induced EMF over one complete cycle is zero.
Consider the average EMF over the interval from 0 to 60 degrees.
The average EMF \( \overline{\mathcal{E}} \) is given by: \( \overline{\mathcal{E}} = \frac{1}{\theta_{\text{max}}} \int_{0}^{\theta_{\text{max}}} \mathcal{E}(\theta) \, d\theta \).
The average value of the induced EMF is \( \boxed{\frac{\sqrt{3}}{12} B S \omega} \).
